1. (30 points) An ecologist is interested in the intermediate disturbance hypothesis (IDH) 
that postulates that the highest species richness should be found at intermediate levels of 
disturbance. Write a  likelihood function to estimate the  
parameters for a quadratic regression models given in Beckage and Stout 2000 
(http://www.uvm.edu/~bbeckage/Manuscripts/BeckageStout.corrected.2000.jvs.pdf), 
but assuming a Poisson likelihood with a log link function.  Provide your i. likelihood function and supporting R code for finding the MLE's, ii. a plot of the data with the fitted line and iii. report the regression parameters (bo, b1, and b2), and iv. the value of the negative log likelihood at the MLEs.  Note: You must write your own likelihood function and not use a built in R function or package, e.g, lm, glm, etc.

The data may be read using:
```{r}
srDat<-read.table("http://www.uvm.edu/~bbeckage/Teaching/PBIO_294/Data/idh.csv",sep=',',header=TRUE)
```

Quadratic equation (Beckage and Stout 2000): Y= B0 + B1(Burns) + B2(Burns)^2  

```{r}
  nllPois<-function(parVec,data){
      sr<-data$sr
      burns<-data$nFires
      b0<-parVec[1]
      b1<-parVec[2]
      b2<-parVec[3]
      srPred<-exp(b0+b1*burns+b2*burns^2)
      nllik<- -sum(dpois(x=sr,lambda=srPred,log=TRUE))
      return(nllik)
  }

parVec<-c(0,0,0)
nllPois(parVec,srDat)

outPois<-optim(par=parVec,fn=nllPois,data=srDat)
outPois$par # b0 = 2.06398335  b1 = 0.43982406  b2= -0.04545478
outPois$val # nllik = 848
```
```{r}
sr<-srDat$sr
burns<-srDat$nFires
burns_pred<-burns[order(burns)]
plot(burns,sr,ylab="Species Richness",xlab="No. Burns")
lines(burns_pred, exp(outPois$par[1]+outPois$par[2]*burns_pred+outPois$par[3]*burns_pred^2),col='red',lwd=2)
```

2. (30 points) Repeat exercise 1 except now fitting the model using either Rstan or Rjags.  You must write your own Stan/JAGS model, meaning that you can not use one of the Stan helper libraries such as the brms or rstanarm libraries. Provide your i. Stan/JAGS model code and supporting R code for running the Stan/JAGS model, ii. report the 2.5%, 50%, and 97.5% percentiles for the regression parameters (bo, b1, and b2), iii. plot the posterior distributions for each of these parameters and iv. assess the convergence of your chains using the Gelman-Rubin statistic.

```{r}
library(rjags)
sr<-srDat$sr
burns<-srDat$nFires
```


```{r}
modelString<-"
model {
  for (i in 1:N){
    sr[i] ~ dpois(lam.hat[i])
    log(lam.hat[i]) <- beta0 + beta1*burns[i] + beta2*burns[i]^2
  }
  beta0 ~ dnorm(0, .0001)
  beta1 ~ dnorm(0, .0001)
  beta2 ~ dnorm(0, .0001)
}
"
writeLines(modelString, con='poissonReg.jags.txt')
```

```{r}
jags <- jags.model('poissonReg.jags.txt',
                   data = list('sr' = sr,
                               'burns' = burns,
                               'N' = length(burns)),
                   inits<-list(
                       list('beta0'=1,'beta1'=2,'beta2'=3),
                       list('beta0'=1,'beta1'=.2,'beta2'=0),
                       list('beta0'=.1,'beta1'=2,'beta2'=.1),
                       list('beta0'=0,'beta1'=5,'beta2'=1)),
                   n.chains = 4,
                   n.adapt = 100)
```

```{r}
update(jags, 1000)

jags.samples(jags,
             c('beta0', 'beta1', 'beta2'),
             10000)

# b0 = 2.068815, b1 = 0.4377214, b2 = -0.04527253
```
```{r}
library(coda)
codaSamples<-coda.samples(jags, c('beta0','beta1','beta2'), 10000, 1)
```

```{r}
plot(codaSamples, trace = FALSE, density = TRUE)
traceplot(codaSamples)
```


```{r}
summary(codaSamples) 
# This gives means for parameter estimates (though these are already reported above) and the confidence intervals (quantiles) surrounding these estimates.

# 1. Empirical mean and standard deviation for each variable,
#    plus standard error of the mean:

#           Mean       SD  Naive SE Time-series SE
# beta0  2.06826 0.061232 3.062e-04      0.0036315
# beta1  0.43780 0.025361 1.268e-04      0.0017845
# beta2 -0.04527 0.002319 1.159e-05      0.0001514

# 2. Quantiles for each variable:

#           2.5%      25%      50%      75%    97.5%
# beta0  1.94536  2.02798  2.06801  2.11014  2.18614
# beta1  0.38891  0.42062  0.43788  0.45458  0.48882
# beta2 -0.04989 -0.04679 -0.04527 -0.04371 -0.04079
```

```{r}
# gelman.diag() in the coda package is a Gelman and Rubinâ€™s convergence diagnostic tool.

gelman.diag(x=codaSamples, confidence = 0.95, transform=FALSE, autoburnin=TRUE,
multivariate=TRUE)

# Scale reduction factors <1.1 are "ok", so convergence was reached for all three parameters (b0 = 1.00, b1 = 1.01, b2 = 1.01)
```

3. (40 points) An ecologist expects seed predation to be influenced by the presence of openings (gaps) in the forest overstory and seed mass. The effect of seed mass on predation is expected to be quadratic:  Small seeds will be less predated because they offer a lower energetic reward while larger seeds will be too difficult to process, so that medium sized seeds will be most predated.  The effect of a gap is additive with lower predation expected in gaps because seed predators avoid areas of open canopy. The ecologist models the data as a hierarchical logistic regression, assuming that the seed masses are known without observation error.  The model has the form:

Seed lost ~ Binomial(theta) # 1 if seed is predated, 0 if seed is left alone
Logit(theta) = b0i + b1 x gap 
b0i ~ gamma(mu^2/sd^2,mu/sd^2) 
mui = b2 + b3 x seed mass i - b4 x (seed mass i)^2 
sd^2 ~ gamma(0.001,0.001)
b1,b2,b3,b4 ~ normal(0,100)

Fit this model using either Rstan or Rjags.  You must write your own Stan/JAGS model, meaning that you can not use one of the Stan helper libraries such as the brms or rstanarm libraries. Provide your i. *Stan/JAGS model code and supporting R code for running the Stan/JAGS model*, ii. report the *2.5%, 50%, and 97.5% percentiles for the regression parameters (b1, b1, b2, b3, and b4)*, iii. *plot the posterior distributions for each of these parameters* and iv. *assess the convergence of your chains using the Gelman-Rubin statistic.*

The data can be read using:
```{r}
seeds<-read.table("http://www.uvm.edu/~bbeckage/Teaching/PBIO_294/Data/seeds.csv",sep=',',header=TRUE)
seedID<-seq(from=1,to=1000,by=1)
seeds_ID<-cbind(seedID,seeds)
```

```{r}
data<-seeds_ID
lostName<-'seedLost'
massName<-'mass'
IDName<-'seedID'
gapName<-'gap'
seedLost<-data[[lostName]]
mass<-data[[massName]]
seedID<-data[[IDName]]
gap<-data[[gapName]]
Nsubj<-length(unique(seedID))
Ngap<-length(unique(gap))
N<-length(seedID)


# Compile all data to a list, make sure all variables are numeric (not factors)
dataList = list(
  seedLost = seedLost ,
  mass = mass ,
  gap = as.numeric(gap) ,
  N = N
)
```


```{r}

modelstring = "
model {
    for ( i in 1:N ) {
    seedLost ~ dbinom(theta)
    log(theta) = b0[i] + b1 * gap
    b0[i] ~ dgamma(gam1,gam2)
    log(mu[i]) = b2 + b3 * mass[i] - b4 * mass[i]^2
    gam1<-mu^2/sd
    gam2<-mu/sd
}

    sd ~ dgamma(0.001,0.001)
    b1 ~ dnorm(0,100)
    b2 ~ dnorm(0,100)
    b3 ~ dnorm(0,100)
    b4 ~ dnorm(0,100)
}
" 
writeLines( modelstring , con="seedmodel.txt" )
```


```{r}
require(rjags)
require(coda)

parameters<-c("b0","b1","b2","b3","b4") 
adaptSteps<-500 
burnInSteps<-1000  
jagsModel<-jags.model("seedmodel.txt", data=dataList) # Something is going wrong with my b0[i] ~ dgamma line. Cannot figure this part out.

update(jagsModel, n.iter=burnInSteps)
  
codaSamples = coda.samples(jagsModel, variable.names=parameters, 
                                n.iter=10000, 
                                thin=5)
plot(codaSamples, trace = FALSE, density = TRUE)

HPDinterval(codaSamples)
summary(codaSamples)
traceplot(codaSamples)

```
